headline: Northrop's Arm Secures a Contract to Support E-2D Hawkeye Jets
summary: NOC's unit secures a $44.5M Navy deal to enhance E-2D Hawkeye landing operations through 2027.

raw.headline: Northrop's Arm Secures a Contract to Support E-2D Hawkeye Jets

headline: Airbus, Honeywell, Lockheed Martin, RTX, and Safran Lead in Digital Transformation Among Aerospace and Defense Manufacturers, According to ABI Research Index
summary: Airbus has secured the top position in ABI Research's Digital Transformation Benchmarking Index for Large Aerospace and Defense (A&D) Manufacturers, followed by Honeywell, Lockheed Martin, RTX (formerly Raytheon Technologies), and Safran in an evaluation of 21 leading firms in the sector.

raw.headline: Airbus, Honeywell, Lockheed Martin, RTX, and Safran Lead in Digital Transformation Among Aerospace and Defense Manufacturers, According to ABI Research Index

headline: Evaluating Lockheed Martin as Drone Sales Expand After White House Policy Shift in 2025
summary: Trying to decide what to do with Lockheed Martin stock right now? You are not alone. After a rollercoaster year for defense names, Lockheed is back in focus, with recent headlines driving both optimism and a fresh look at risk. In just the past month, shares have climbed 7.4%, and over the last week, the stock notched a solid 2.0% gain. While that is a nice reversal from the disappointing 14.0% loss over the past year, there is still plenty to unpack if you are wondering whether this is...

headline: Small US defense stocks soar on rush for next-gen battlefield tech
summary: (Reuters) -Smaller U.S. defense firms have emerged as standout performers on Wall Street this year, fueled by surging demand for low-cost, next-generation military tech tailored for modern warfare and the Pentagon's pivot toward agile and adaptable combat systems.  Wars in Ukraine and Gaza have spurred a rise in military spending across the globe, lifting defense stocks and drawing investors to smaller firms specializing in AI-powered drones and unmanned vehicles that are cheap, easily deployable and help cut dependence on ground troops.  "The winners in this new market will be those companies leaning into the change and investing in low-cost, upgradable, and software-enabled weapon systems," said Jon Siegmann, managing director covering the aerospace and defense industry at Stifel.
